85 /**
86  Mixin class for classes which have an array of arguments ('args') and a
87  count of them ('arg_count').
88  Used by Item_func and Item_sum.
89 */
90 class Func_args_handle {
91  protected:
92  /**
93  Array of pointers to arguments. If there are max 2 arguments, this array
94  is often just m_embedded_arguments; otherwise it's explicitly allocated in
95  the constructor.
96  */
97  Item **args;
98  Item *m_embedded_arguments[2];
99 
100  public:
101  uint arg_count; ///< How many arguments in 'args'
102  Func_args_handle() = default;
103  virtual ~Func_args_handle() = default;
104  Func_args_handle(uint c) : args(m_embedded_arguments), arg_count(c) {}
105  Func_args_handle(Item **a, uint c) : args(a), arg_count(c) {}
106  /// Changes argument and maintains any necessary invariants.
107  virtual void set_arg_resolve(THD *, uint i, Item *arg) { args[i] = arg; }
108  Item *func_arg(uint i) { return args[i]; }
109  Item *set_func_arg(THD *thd, uint i, Item *new_val);
110  virtual uint argument_count() const { return arg_count; }
111  inline Item **arguments() const {
112  return (argument_count() > 0) ? args : nullptr;
113  }
114 
115  protected:
116  /*
117  These decide of types of arguments which are prepared-statement
118  parameters.
119  */
120  bool param_type_uses_non_param(THD *thd,
121  enum_field_types def = MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR);
122  bool param_type_is_default(THD *thd, uint start, uint end, uint step,
123  enum_field_types def);
124  bool param_type_is_default(THD *thd, uint start, uint end,
125  enum_field_types def = MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR) {
126  return param_type_is_default(thd, start, end, 1, def);
127  }
128  bool param_type_is_rejected(uint start, uint end);
129 };

136  /**
137  Affects how to determine that NULL argument implies a NULL function return.
138  Default behaviour in this class is:
139  - if true, any NULL argument means the function returns NULL.
140  - if false, no such assumption is made and not_null_tables_cache is thus
141  set to 0.
142  null_on_null is true for all Item_func derived classes, except Item_func_sp,
143  all CASE derived functions and a few other functions.
144  RETURNS NULL ON NULL INPUT can be implemented for stored functions by
145  modifying this member in class Item_func_sp.
146  */

310  Item_func(Item *a, Item *b, Item *c) {
311  if ((args = (Item **)(*THR_MALLOC)->Alloc(sizeof(Item *) * 3))) {
312  arg_count = 3;
313  args[0] = a;
314  args[1] = b;
315  args[2] = c;
316  m_accum_properties = 0;
317  add_accum_properties(a);
318  add_accum_properties(b);
319  add_accum_properties(c);
320  } else
321  arg_count = 0; // OOM
322  }
323

498  /**
499  Throw an error if the input double number is not finite, i.e. is either
500  +/-INF or NAN.
501  */
502  inline double check_float_overflow(double value) {
503  return std::isfinite(value) ? value : raise_float_overflow();
504  }
505  /**
506  Throw an error if the input BIGINT value represented by the
507  (longlong value, bool unsigned flag) pair cannot be returned by the
508  function, i.e. is not compatible with this Item's unsigned_flag.
509  */
510  inline longlong check_integer_overflow(longlong value, bool val_unsigned) {
511  if ((unsigned_flag && !val_unsigned && value < 0) ||
512  (!unsigned_flag && val_unsigned &&
513  (ulonglong)value > (ulonglong)LLONG_MAX))
514  return raise_integer_overflow();
515  return value;
516  }
517  /**
518  Throw an error if the error code of a DECIMAL operation is E_DEC_OVERFLOW.
519  */
520  inline int check_decimal_overflow(int error) {
521  return (error == E_DEC_OVERFLOW) ? raise_decimal_overflow() : error;
522  }

524  bool has_timestamp_args() {
525  DBUG_ASSERT(fixed);
526  for (uint i = 0; i < arg_count; i++) {
527  if (args[i]->type() == Item::FIELD_ITEM &&
528  args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP)
529  return true;
530  }
531  return false;
532  }
533 
534  bool has_date_args() {
535  DBUG_ASSERT(fixed);
536  for (uint i = 0; i < arg_count; i++) {
537  if (args[i]->type() == Item::FIELD_ITEM &&
538  (args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_DATE ||
539  args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME))
540  return true;
541  }
542  return false;
543  }
544 
545  bool has_time_args() {
546  DBUG_ASSERT(fixed);
547  for (uint i = 0; i < arg_count; i++) {
548  if (args[i]->type() == Item::FIELD_ITEM &&
549  (args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_TIME ||
550  args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME))
551  return true;
552  }
553  return false;
554  }
555 
556  bool has_datetime_args() {
557  DBUG_ASSERT(fixed);
558  for (uint i = 0; i < arg_count; i++) {
559  if (args[i]->type() == Item::FIELD_ITEM &&
560  args[i]->data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME)
561  return true;
562  }
563  return false;
564  }
565 
566  /*
567  We assume the result of any function that has a TIMESTAMP argument to be
568  timezone-dependent, since a TIMESTAMP value in both numeric and string
569  contexts is interpreted according to the current timezone.
570  The only exception is UNIX_TIMESTAMP() which returns the internal
571  representation of a TIMESTAMP argument verbatim, and thus does not depend on
572  the timezone.
573  */
574  bool check_valid_arguments_processor(uchar *) override {
575  return has_timestamp_args();
576  }

585  /**
586  Whether an arg of a JSON function can be cached to avoid repetitive
587  string->JSON conversion. This function returns true only for those args,
588  which are the source of JSON data. JSON path args are cached independently
589  and for them this function returns false. Same as for all other type of
590  args.
591 
592  @param arg the arg to cache
593 
594  @retval true arg can be cached
595  @retval false otherwise
596  */
597  virtual enum_const_item_cache can_cache_json_arg(
598  Item *arg MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
599  return CACHE_NONE;

602  /// Whether this Item is an equi-join condition. If this Item is a compound
603  /// item (i.e. multiple condition AND'ed together), it will only return true
604  /// if the Item contains only equi-join conditions AND'ed together. This is
605  /// used to determine whether the condition can be used as a join condition
606  /// for hash join (join conditions in hash join must be equi-join conditions),
607  /// or if it should be placed as a filter after the join.
608  virtual bool contains_only_equi_join_condition() const { return false; }
609 
610  bool ensure_multi_equality_fields_are_available_walker(uchar *) override;
611 
612  protected:
613  /**
614  Whether or not an item should contribute to the filtering effect
615  (@see get_filtering_effect()). First it verifies that table
616  requirements are satisfied as follows:
617 
618  1) The item must refer to a field in 'filter_for_table' in some
619  way. This reference may be indirect through any number of
620  intermediate items. For example, this item may be an
621  Item_cond_and which refers to an Item_func_eq which refers to
622  the field.
623  2) The item must not refer to other tables than those already
624  read and the table in 'filter_for_table'
625 
626  Then it contines to other properties as follows:
627 
628  Item_funcs represent "<operand1> OP <operand2> [OP ...]". If the
629  Item_func is to contribute to the filtering effect, then
630 
631  1) one of the operands must be a field from 'filter_for_table' that is not
632  in 'fields_to_ignore', and
633  2) depending on the Item_func type filtering effect is calculated
634  for, one or all [1] of the other operand(s) must be an available
635  value, i.e.:
636  - a constant, or
637  - a constant subquery, or
638  - a field value read from a table in 'read_tables', or
639  - a second field in 'filter_for_table', or
640  - a function that only refers to constants or tables in
641  'read_tables', or
642  - special case: an implicit value like NULL in the case of
643  "field IS NULL". Such Item_funcs have arg_count==1.
644 
645  [1] "At least one" for multiple equality (X = Y = Z = ...), "all"
646  for the rest (e.g. BETWEEN)
647 
648  @param read_tables Tables earlier in the join sequence.
649  Predicates for table 'filter_for_table' that
650  rely on values from these tables can be part of
651  the filter effect.
652  @param filter_for_table The table we are calculating filter effect for
653  @param fields_to_ignore Columns that should be ignored.
654 
655 
656  @return Item_field that participates in the predicate if none of the
657  requirements are broken, NULL otherwise
658 
659  @note: This function only applies to items doing comparison, i.e.
660  boolean predicates. Unfortunately, some of those items do not
661  inherit from Item_bool_func so the member function has to be
662  placed in Item_func.
663  */
664  const Item_field *contributes_to_filter(
665  table_map read_tables, table_map filter_for_table,
666  const MY_BITMAP *fields_to_ignore) const;
667  /**
668  Named parameters are allowed in a parameter list
669 
670  The syntax to name parameters in a function call is as follow:
671  <code>foo(expr AS named, expr named, expr AS "named", expr "named")</code>
672  where "AS" is optional.
673  Only UDF function support that syntax.
674 
675  @return true if the function item can have named parameters
676  */
677  virtual bool may_have_named_parameters() const { return false; }
678  bool is_non_const_over_literals(uchar *) override { return false; }
679 
680  bool check_function_as_value_generator(uchar *checker_args) override {
681  if (is_deprecated()) {
682  Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters *func_arg =
683  pointer_cast<Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters *>(
684  checker_args);
685  func_arg->banned_function_name = func_name();
686  return true;
687  }
688  return false;
689  }
690  bool check_column_from_derived_table(
691  uchar *arg MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) override {
692  return false;
693  }
694  bool check_column_in_window_functions(uchar *arg) override;
695  bool check_column_in_group_by(uchar *arg) override;
696 
697  longlong val_int_from_real();
698 };
699

1395 
1396  @retval RAND_TABLE_BIT
1397  */
1398  table_map get_initial_pseudo_tables() const override {

1410  checker_args);
1411  func_arg->banned_function_name = func_name();
1412  return ((func_arg->source == VGS_GENERATED_COLUMN) ||
1413  (func_arg->source == VGS_CHECK_CONSTRAINT));
1414  }

1456 class Item_func_min_max : public Item_func_numhybrid {

1459  : Item_func_numhybrid(pos, opt_list),
1460  m_is_least_func(is_least_func),
1461  temporal_item(nullptr) {}
1462 
1463  longlong val_int() override;

1466  longlong int_op() override;

1469  String *str_op(String *) override;

1471  bool time_op(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) override;
1472  enum_field_types default_data_type() const override {
1473  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;

1480  /**
1481  Make CAST(LEAST_OR_GREATEST(datetime_expr, varchar_expr))
1482  return a number in format YYMMDDhhmmss.
1483  */
1484  enum Item_result cast_to_int_type() const override {
1485  return compare_as_dates() ? INT_RESULT : result_type();
1486  }
1487 
1488  /// Returns true if arguments to this function should be compared as dates.
1489  bool compare_as_dates() const {
1490  return temporal_item != nullptr &&
1491  is_temporal_type_with_date(temporal_item->data_type());
1492  }
1493 
1494  /// Returns true if at least one of the arguments was of temporal type.
1495  bool has_temporal_arg() const { return temporal_item; }
1496 
1497  private:
1498  /// True if LEAST function, false if GREATEST.
1499  const bool m_is_least_func;
1500  String m_string_buf;
1501  /*
1502  Used for determining whether one of the arguments is of temporal type and
1503  for converting arguments to a common output format if arguments are
1504  compared as dates and result type is character string. For example,
1505  LEAST('95-05-05', date '10-10-10') should return '1995-05-05', not
1506  '95-05-05'.
1507  */
1508  Item *temporal_item;
1509  /**
1510  Compare arguments as datetime values.
1511 
1512  @param value Pointer to which the datetime value of the winning argument
1513  is written.
1514 
1515  @return true if error, false otherwise.
1516  */
1517  bool cmp_datetimes(longlong *value);
1518

1520  Compare arguments as time values.
1521

1523  written.
1524 
1525  @return true if error, false otherwise.
1526  */

1528 };

1545 
1546 /**
1547  A wrapper Item that normally returns its parameter, but becomes NULL when
1548  processing rows for rollup. Rollup is implemented by AggregateIterator, and
1549  works by means of hierarchical levels -- 0 is the “grand totals” phase, 1 is
1550  where only one group level is active, and so on. E.g., for a query with GROUP
1551  BY a,b, the rows will look like this:
1552 
1553  a b rollup level
1554  1 1 2
1555  1 2 2
1556  1 NULL 1
1557  2 1 2
1558  2 NULL 1
1559  NULL NULL 0
1560 
1561  Each rollup group item has a minimum level for when it becomes NULL. In the
1562  example above, a would have minimum level 0 and b would have minimum level 1.
1563  For simplicity, the JOIN carries a list of all rollup group items, and they
1564  are being given the current rollup level when it changes. A rollup level of
1565  INT_MAX essentially always disables rollup, which is useful when there are
1566  leftover group items in places that are not relevant for rollup
1567  (e.g., sometimes resolving can leave rollup wrappers in place for temporary
1568  tables that are created before grouping, which should then effectively be
1569  disabled).
1570  */
1571 class Item_rollup_group_item final : public Item_func {
1572  public:
1573  Item_rollup_group_item(int min_rollup_level, Item *inner_item)
1574  : Item_func(inner_item), m_min_rollup_level(min_rollup_level) {
1575  item_name = inner_item->item_name;
1576  max_length = inner_item->max_length;
1577  set_data_type(inner_item->data_type());
1578  collation = inner_item->collation;
1579  // We're going to replace inner_item in the SELECT list, so copy its hidden
1580  // status. (We could have done this in the caller, but it fits naturally in
1581  // with all the other copying done here.)
1582  hidden = inner_item->hidden;
1583  maybe_null = true;
1584  set_rollup_expr();
1585  }
1586  double val_real() override;
1587  longlong val_int() override;
1588  String *val_str(String *str) override;
1589  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *dec) override;
1590  bool val_json(Json_wrapper *result) override;
1591  bool get_date(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate) override;
1592  bool get_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) override;
1593  const char *func_name() const override { return "rollup_group_item"; }
1594  table_map used_tables() const override {
1595  /*
1596  If underlying item is non-constant, return its used_tables value.
1597  Otherwise, ensure it is non-constant by returning RAND_TABLE_BIT.
1598  */
1599  return args[0]->used_tables() ? args[0]->used_tables() : RAND_TABLE_BIT;
1600  }
1601  Item_result result_type() const override { return args[0]->result_type(); }
1602  bool resolve_type(THD *) override {
1603  // needn't handle dynamic parameter as its const_item() is false.
1604  set_data_type_from_item(args[0]);
1605 
1606  // The item could be a NULL constant.
1607  null_value = args[0]->is_null();
1608  return false;
1609  }
1610  Item *inner_item() const { return args[0]; }
1611  bool rollup_null() const {
1612  return m_current_rollup_level <= m_min_rollup_level;
1613  }
1614  enum Functype functype() const override { return ROLLUP_GROUP_ITEM_FUNC; }
1615  void print(const THD *thd, String *str,
1616  enum_query_type query_type) const override;
1617 
1618  // Used by AggregateIterator.
1619  void set_current_rollup_level(int level) { m_current_rollup_level = level; }
1620 
1621  // Used when cloning the item only.
1622  int min_rollup_level() const { return m_min_rollup_level; }
1623 
1624  private:
1625  const int m_min_rollup_level;
1626  int m_current_rollup_level = INT_MAX;
1627 };

1776 class Item_func_bit : public Item_func {
1777  protected:
1778  /// Stores the Item's result type. Can only be INT_RESULT or STRING_RESULT
1779  Item_result hybrid_type;
1780  /// Buffer storing the determined value
1781  String tmp_value;
1782  /**
1783  @returns true if the second argument should be of binary type for the
1784  result to be of binary type.
1785  */
1786  virtual bool binary_result_requires_binary_second_arg() const = 0;
1787 
1788  public:
1789  Item_func_bit(const POS &pos, Item *a, Item *b) : Item_func(pos, a, b) {}
1790  Item_func_bit(const POS &pos, Item *a) : Item_func(pos, a) {}
1791 
1792  bool resolve_type(THD *) override;
1793  enum Item_result result_type() const override { return hybrid_type; }
1794 
1795  longlong val_int() override;
1796  String *val_str(String *str) override;
1797  double val_real() override;
1798  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *decimal_value) override;
1799 
1800  void print(const THD *thd, String *str,
1801  enum_query_type query_type) const override {
1802  print_op(thd, str, query_type);
1803  }
1804  bool get_date(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate) override {
1805  if (hybrid_type == INT_RESULT)
1806  return get_date_from_int(ltime, fuzzydate);
1807  else
1808  return get_date_from_string(ltime, fuzzydate);
1809  }
1810  bool get_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) override {
1811  if (hybrid_type == INT_RESULT)
1812  return get_time_from_int(ltime);
1813  else
1814  return get_time_from_string(ltime);
1815  }
1816 
1817  private:
1818  /**
1819  @brief Performs the operation on integers to produce a result of type
1820  INT_RESULT.
1821  @return The result of the operation.
1822  */
1823  virtual longlong int_op() = 0;
1824 
1825  /**
1826  @brief Performs the operation on binary strings to produce a result of
1827  type STRING_RESULT.
1828  @return The result of the operation.
1829  */
1830  virtual String *str_op(String *) = 0;
1831 };

2057 class Item_udf_func : public Item_func {
2058  typedef Item_func super;
2059 
2060  protected:
2061  udf_handler udf;
2062  bool is_expensive_processor(uchar *) override { return true; }
2063 
2064  public:
2065  Item_udf_func(const POS &pos, udf_func *udf_arg, PT_item_list *opt_list)
2066  : Item_func(pos, opt_list), udf(udf_arg) {
2067  null_on_null = false;
2068  }
2069  ~Item_udf_func() override {}
2070 
2071  bool itemize(Parse_context *pc, Item **res) override;
2072  const char *func_name() const override { return udf.name(); }
2073  enum Functype functype() const override { return UDF_FUNC; }
2074  bool fix_fields(THD *thd, Item **ref) override;
2075  void update_used_tables() override {
2076  /*
2077  TODO: Make a member in UDF_INIT and return if a UDF is deterministic or
2078  not.
2079  Currently UDF_INIT has a member (const_item) that is an in/out
2080  parameter to the init() call.
2081  The code in udf_handler::fix_fields also duplicates the arguments
2082  handling code in Item_func::fix_fields().
2083 
2084  The lack of information if a UDF is deterministic makes writing
2085  a correct update_used_tables() for UDFs impossible.
2086  One solution to this would be :
2087  - Add a is_deterministic member of UDF_INIT
2088  - (optionally) deprecate the const_item member of UDF_INIT
2089  - Take away the duplicate code from udf_handler::fix_fields() and
2090  make Item_udf_func call Item_func::fix_fields() to process its
2091  arguments as for any other function.
2092  - Store the deterministic flag returned by <udf>_init into the
2093  udf_handler.
2094  - Don't implement Item_udf_func::fix_fields, implement
2095  Item_udf_func::resolve_type() instead (similar to non-UDF functions).
2096  - Override Item_func::update_used_tables to call
2097  Item_func::update_used_tables() and add a RAND_TABLE_BIT to the
2098  result of Item_func::update_used_tables() if the UDF is
2099  non-deterministic.
2100  - (optionally) rename RAND_TABLE_BIT to NONDETERMINISTIC_BIT to
2101  better describe its usage.
2102 
2103  The above would require a change of the UDF API.
2104  Until that change is done here's how the current code works:
2105  We call Item_func::update_used_tables() only when we know that
2106  the function depends on real non-const tables and is deterministic.
2107  This can be done only because we know that the optimizer will
2108  call update_used_tables() only when there's possibly a new const
2109  table. So update_used_tables() can only make a Item_func more
2110  constant than it is currently.
2111  That's why we don't need to do anything if a function is guaranteed
2112  to return non-constant (it's non-deterministic) or is already a
2113  const.
2114  */
2115  if ((used_tables_cache & ~PSEUDO_TABLE_BITS) &&
2116  !(used_tables_cache & RAND_TABLE_BIT))
2117  Item_func::update_used_tables();
2118 
2119  not_null_tables_cache = 0;
2120  DBUG_ASSERT(!null_on_null); // no need to update not_null_tables_cache
2121  }
2122  void cleanup() override;
2123  Item_result result_type() const override { return udf.result_type(); }
2124  bool is_expensive() override { return true; }
2125  void print(const THD *thd, String *str,
2126  enum_query_type query_type) const override;
2127 
2128  bool check_function_as_value_generator(uchar *checker_args) override {
2129  Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters *func_arg =
2130  pointer_cast<Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters *>(
2131  checker_args);
2132  func_arg->banned_function_name = func_name();
2133  return true;
2134  }
2135 
2136  protected:
2137  bool may_have_named_parameters() const override { return true; }
2138 };
2139

2235  dec_buf);

2237  }

2239  return get_date_from_string(ltime, fuzzydate);
2240  }

2991 /* Handling of user definable variables */
2992 
2993 // this is needed for user_vars hash
2994 class user_var_entry {
2995  void reset_value() {
2996  m_ptr = nullptr;
2997  m_length = 0;
2998  }
2999  void set_value(char *value, size_t length) {
3000  m_ptr = value;
3001  m_length = length;
3002  }
3003 
3004  /**
3005  Position inside a user_var_entry where small values are stored:
3006  double values, longlong values and string values with length
3007  up to extra_size (should be 8 bytes on all platforms).
3008  String values with length longer than 8 are stored in a separate
3009  memory buffer, which is allocated when needed using the method realloc().
3010  */
3011  char *internal_buffer_ptr() {
3012  return pointer_cast<char *>(this) + ALIGN_SIZE(sizeof(user_var_entry));
3013  }
3014 
3015  /**
3016  Position inside a user_var_entry where a null-terminates array
3017  of characters representing the variable name is stored.
3018  */
3019  char *name_ptr() { return internal_buffer_ptr() + extra_size; }
3020 
3021  /**
3022  Initialize m_ptr to the internal buffer (if the value is small enough),
3023  or allocate a separate buffer.
3024  @param length - length of the value to be stored.
3025  */
3026  bool mem_realloc(size_t length);
3027 
3028  /**
3029  Check if m_ptr point to an external buffer previously alloced by realloc().
3030  @retval true - an external buffer is alloced.
3031  @retval false - m_ptr is null, or points to the internal buffer.
3032  */
3033  bool alloced() { return m_ptr && m_ptr != internal_buffer_ptr(); }
3034 
3035  /**
3036  Free the external value buffer, if it's allocated.
3037  */
3038  void free_value() {
3039  if (alloced()) my_free(m_ptr);
3040  }
3041 
3042  /**
3043  Copy the array of characters from the given name into the internal
3044  name buffer and initialize entry_name to point to it.
3045  */
3046  void copy_name(const Simple_cstring &name) {
3047  name.strcpy(name_ptr());
3048  entry_name = Name_string(name_ptr(), name.length());
3049  }
3050 
3051  /**
3052  Initialize all members
3053 
3054  @param thd Current session.
3055  @param name Name of the user_var_entry instance.
3056  @param cs charset information of the user_var_entry instance.
3057  */
3058  void init(THD *thd, const Simple_cstring &name, const CHARSET_INFO *cs);
3059 
3060  /**
3061  Store a value of the given type into a user_var_entry instance.
3062  @param from Value
3063  @param length Size of the value
3064  @param type type
3065  @retval false on success
3066  @retval true on memory allocation error
3067  */
3068  bool store(const void *from, size_t length, Item_result type);
3069 
3070  /**
3071  Assert the user variable is locked.
3072  This is debug code only.
3073  The thread LOCK_thd_data mutex protects:
3074  - the thd->user_vars hash itself
3075  - the values in the user variable itself.
3076  The protection is required for monitoring,
3077  as a different thread can inspect this session
3078  user variables, on a live session.
3079  */
3080  void assert_locked() const;
3081 
3082  static const size_t extra_size = sizeof(double);
3083  char *m_ptr; ///< Value
3084  size_t m_length; ///< Value length
3085  Item_result m_type; ///< Value type
3086  THD *m_owner;
3087  /**
3088  Set to the id of the most recent query that has used the variable.
3089  Used in binlogging: When set, there is no need to add a reference to this
3090  variable to the binlog. Imagine it is this:
3091 
3092  INSERT INTO t SELECT @a:=10, @a:=@a+1.
3093 
3094  Then we have a Item_func_get_user_var (because of the `@a+1`) so we
3095  think we have to write the value of `@a` to the binlog. But before that,
3096  we have a Item_func_set_user_var to create `@a` (`@a:=10`), in this we mark
3097  the variable as "already logged" so that it won't be logged
3098  by Item_func_get_user_var (because that's not necessary).
3099  */
3100  query_id_t m_used_query_id;
3101 
3102  public:
3103  user_var_entry() {} /* Remove gcc warning */
3104 
3105  THD *owner_session() const { return m_owner; }
3106 
3107  Simple_cstring entry_name; // Variable name
3108  DTCollation collation; // Collation with attributes
3109  bool unsigned_flag; // true if unsigned, false if signed
3110 
3111  /**
3112  Set value to user variable.
3113 
3114  @param ptr pointer to buffer with new value
3115  @param length length of new value
3116  @param type type of new value
3117  @param cs charset info for new value
3118  @param dv derivation for new value
3119  @param unsigned_arg indiates if a value of type INT_RESULT is unsigned
3120 
3121  @note Sets error and fatal error if allocation fails.
3122 
3123  @retval
3124  false success
3125  @retval
3126  true failure
3127  */
3128  bool store(const void *ptr, size_t length, Item_result type,
3129  const CHARSET_INFO *cs, Derivation dv, bool unsigned_arg);
3130  /**
3131  Set type of to the given value.
3132  @param type Data type.
3133  */
3134  void set_type(Item_result type) {
3135  assert_locked();
3136  m_type = type;
3137  }
3138  /**
3139  Set value to NULL
3140  @param type Data type.
3141  */
3142 
3143  void set_null_value(Item_result type) {
3144  assert_locked();
3145  free_value();
3146  reset_value();
3147  m_type = type;
3148  }
3149 
3150  void set_used_query_id(query_id_t query_id) { m_used_query_id = query_id; }
3151  query_id_t used_query_id() const { return m_used_query_id; }
3152 
3153  /**
3154  Allocates and initializes a user variable instance.
3155 
3156  @param thd Current session.
3157  @param name Name of the variable.
3158  @param cs Charset of the variable.
3159 
3160  @return Address of the allocated and initialized user_var_entry instance.
3161  @retval NULL On allocation error.
3162  */
3163  static user_var_entry *create(THD *thd, const Name_string &name,
3164  const CHARSET_INFO *cs);
3165 
3166  /**
3167  Free all memory used by a user_var_entry instance
3168  previously created by create().
3169  */
3170  void destroy() {
3171  assert_locked();
3172  free_value(); // Free the external value buffer
3173  my_free(this); // Free the instance itself
3174  }
3175 
3176  void lock();
3177  void unlock();
3178 
3179  /* Routines to access the value and its type */
3180  const char *ptr() const { return m_ptr; }
3181  size_t length() const { return m_length; }
3182  Item_result type() const { return m_type; }
3183  /* Item-alike routines to access the value */
3184  double val_real(bool *null_value) const;
3185  longlong val_int(bool *null_value) const;
3186  String *val_str(bool *null_value, String *str, uint decimals) const;
3187  my_decimal *val_decimal(bool *null_value, my_decimal *result) const;
3188 };

3519  /**
3520  Get number of matching rows from FT handler.
3521 
3522  @note Requires that FT handler supports the extended API
3523 
3524  @return Number of matching rows in result
3525  */
3526  ulonglong get_count() {
3527  DBUG_ASSERT(ft_handler);
3528  DBUG_ASSERT(table_ref->table->file->ha_table_flags() & HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT);
3529 
3530  return ((FT_INFO_EXT *)ft_handler)
3531  ->could_you->count_matches((FT_INFO_EXT *)ft_handler);
3532  }
3533 
3534  /**
3535  Check whether FT result is ordered on rank
3536 
3537  @return true if result is ordered
3538  @return false otherwise
3539  */
3540  bool ordered_result() {
3541  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3542  if (hints->get_flags() & FT_SORTED) return true;
3543 
3544  if ((table_ref->table->file->ha_table_flags() & HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT) == 0)
3545  return false;
3546 
3547  DBUG_ASSERT(ft_handler);
3548  return ((FT_INFO_EXT *)ft_handler)->could_you->get_flags() &
3549  FTS_ORDERED_RESULT;
3550  }
3551 
3552  /**
3553  Check whether FT result contains the document ID
3554 
3555  @return true if document ID is available
3556  @return false otherwise
3557  */
3558  bool docid_in_result() {
3559  DBUG_ASSERT(ft_handler);
3560 
3561  if ((table_ref->table->file->ha_table_flags() & HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT) == 0)
3562  return false;
3563 
3564  return ((FT_INFO_EXT *)ft_handler)->could_you->get_flags() &
3565  FTS_DOCID_IN_RESULT;
3566  }
3567 
3568  float get_filtering_effect(THD *thd, table_map filter_for_table,
3569  table_map read_tables,
3570  const MY_BITMAP *fields_to_ignore,
3571  double rows_in_table) override;
3572 
3573  /**
3574  Returns master MATCH function.
3575 
3576  @return pointer to master MATCH function.
3577  */
3578  Item_func_match *get_master() {
3579  if (master) return master->get_master();
3580  return this;
3581  }
3582 
3583  /**
3584  Set master MATCH function and adjust used_in_where_only value.
3585 
3586  @param item item for which master should be set.
3587  */
3588  void set_master(Item_func_match *item) {
3589  used_in_where_only &= item->used_in_where_only;
3590  item->master = this;
3591  }
3592 
3593  /**
3594  Returns pointer to Ft_hints object belonging to master MATCH function.
3595 
3596  @return pointer to Ft_hints object
3597  */
3598  Ft_hints *get_hints() {
3599  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3600  return hints;
3601  }
3602 
3603  /**
3604  Set comparison operation type and and value for master MATCH function.
3605 
3606  @param type comparison operation type
3607  @param value_arg comparison operation value
3608  */
3609  void set_hints_op(enum ft_operation type, double value_arg) {
3610  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3611  hints->set_hint_op(type, value_arg);
3612  }
3613 
3614  /**
3615  Set FT hints.
3616  */
3617  void set_hints(JOIN *join, uint ft_flag, ha_rows ft_limit, bool no_cond);
3618 
3619  /**
3620  Check if ranking is not needed.
3621 
3622  @return true if ranking is not needed
3623  @return false otherwise
3624  */
3625  bool can_skip_ranking() {
3626  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3627  return (!(hints->get_flags() & FT_SORTED) && // FT_SORTED is no set
3628  used_in_where_only && // MATCH result is not used
3629  // in expression
3630  hints->get_op_type() == FT_OP_NO); // MATCH is single function
3631  }
3632 
3633  /**
3634  Set flag that the function is a simple expression.
3635 
3636  @param val true if the function is a simple expression, false otherwise
3637  */
3638  void set_simple_expression(bool val) {
3639  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3640  simple_expression = val;
3641  }
3642 
3643  /**
3644  Check if this MATCH function is a simple expression in WHERE condition.
3645 
3646  @return true if simple expression
3647  @return false otherwise
3648  */
3649  bool is_simple_expression() {
3650  DBUG_ASSERT(!master);
3651  return simple_expression;
3652  }
3653 
3654  private:
3655  /**
3656  Fulltext index hints, initialized for master MATCH function only.
3657  */
3658  Ft_hints *hints;
3659  /**
3660  Flag is true when MATCH function is used as a simple expression in
3661  WHERE condition, i.e. there is no AND/OR combinations, just simple
3662  MATCH function or [MATCH, rank] comparison operation.
3663  */
3664  bool simple_expression;
3665  /**
3666  true if MATCH function is used in WHERE condition only.
3667  Used to dermine what hints can be used for FT handler.
3668  Note that only master MATCH function has valid value.
3669  it's ok since only master function is involved in the hint processing.
3670  */
3671  bool used_in_where_only;
3672  /**
3673  Check whether storage engine for given table,
3674  allows FTS Boolean search on non-indexed columns.
3675 
3676  @todo A flag should be added to the extended fulltext API so that
3677  it may be checked whether search on non-indexed columns are
3678  supported. Currently, it is not possible to check for such a
3679  flag since @c this->ft_handler is not yet set when this function is
3680  called. The current hack is to assume that search on non-indexed
3681  columns are supported for engines that does not support the extended
3682  fulltext API (e.g., MyISAM), while it is not supported for other
3683  engines (e.g., InnoDB)
3684 
3685  @param tr Table for which storage engine to check
3686 
3687  @retval true if BOOLEAN search on non-indexed columns is supported
3688  @retval false otherwise
3689  */
3690  bool allows_search_on_non_indexed_columns(const TABLE *tr) {
3691  // Only Boolean search may support non_indexed columns
3692  if (!(flags & FT_BOOL)) return false;
3693 
3694  DBUG_ASSERT(tr && tr->file);
3695 
3696  // Assume that if extended fulltext API is not supported,
3697  // non-indexed columns are allowed. This will be true for MyISAM.
3698  if ((tr->file->ha_table_flags() & HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT) == 0) return true;
3699 
3700  return false;
3701  }
3702 };
